Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement under Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 503 days, resulting in 935 days of physical presence within four years before application
Remedy_Requested: Overturn of citizenship denial and approval of citizenship application
Court_Ruling: Federal Court upheld the Citizenship Judge's decision
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to accumulate 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged incorrect application of residency test by Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard: Residency requires at least 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court from Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of ties to Canada (deemed irrelevant)
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of absence, presence of Canadian ties
Governing_Rule: Residency under Section 5(1)(c) based on physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient days of physical presence in Canada
Cause_Description: Applicant did not meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement for citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Ties to Canada were considered but found irrelevant under physical presence test
Evidence_Issues: Relevance of non-physical presence factors (e.g., ties to Canada)
Evidence_Assessment: Absence of 503 days confirmed; physical presence insufficient
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the physical presence test and provided adequate reasons
Evidentiary_Issues: Exclusion of evidence related to Canadian ties due to strict physical presence interpretation
